questions.question: Which Question paper type of physics as indicated above is given to you
questions.explanation: The header shows "PAPER TYPE: PURPLE".

questions.question: In order to remove the error of parallax when taking measurements with a metre rule, the eye should be focused

options.text: slantingly towards the left on the markings
slantingly towards the right on the markings

questions.explanation: Parallax error is eliminated when the eye is directly above the mark (line of sight perpendicular to the scale).

questions.question: A load is pulled at a uniform speed along horizontal floor by a rope at 45° to floor. If the force in the rope is 1500 N, what is the frictional force on the load?
questions.explanation: Uniform speed implies zero net horizontal force, so friction equals the horizontal component of the pull: \(F\cos 45^\circ=1500\times\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\approx 1061\,\text{N}\).

questions.question: From the velocity-time graph shown above, which of the following quantities CANNOT be determined?
questions.explanation: A velocity–time graph gives initial velocity (value at t=0), deceleration (negative slope segment), and total distance (area under curve). The graph does not provide an initial accelerating segment to measure a nonzero initial acceleration.

questions.question: Calculate the total distance covered by a train before coming to rest if its initial speed is 30 m s^-1 with a constant retardation of 0.1 m s^-2.
A car starts from rest and moves with a uniform acceleration of 30 m s^-2 for 20 s. Calculate the distance covered at the end of the motion.
questions.explanation: From rest: \(s=\tfrac{1}{2}at^2=\tfrac{1}{2}\times 30\times 20^2=15\times 400=6000\,\text{m}=6\,\text{km}\).

questions.question: A rocket is fired from the earth's surface to a distant planet. By Newton’s law of universal gravitation, the force F will
questions.explanation: Gravitational force varies as \(F\propto \frac{1}{r^2}\), so it increases when separation r decreases.

questions.question: If a freely suspended object is pulled to one side and released, it oscillates about the point of suspension because the

options.text: acceleration is directly proportional to the displacement
motion is directed away from the equilibrium point
acceleration is directly proportional to the square of the displacement
velocity is minimum at the equilibrium point

questions.explanation: For small oscillations, the restoring acceleration is proportional to displacement (SHM condition).

questions.question: An object moves in a circular path of radius 0.5 m with a speed of 1 m s^-1. What is its angular velocity?
questions.explanation: Angular velocity \(\omega=\frac{v}{r}=\frac{1}{0.5}=2\,\text{rad s}^{-1}\).

questions.question: From the diagram above, calculate the work done when the particle moves from x = 0 m to x = 80 m.
questions.explanation: Work is the area under the force–distance curve from 0 to 80 m. The region is a triangle with base 80 m and height 60 N, so \(W=\tfrac{1}{2}\times 80\times 60=2400\,\text{J}\).

questions.question: The diagram above shows a wooden block just about to slide down an inclined plane whose inclination to the horizontal is α. The coefficient of frictional force between the block and the plane is
questions.explanation: At limiting equilibrium: \(mg\sin\alpha=\mu mg\cos\alpha\Rightarrow \mu=\tan\alpha\).

questions.question: An object of mass 20 kg slides down an inclined plane at an angle of 30° to the horizontal. The coefficient of an active friction is
questions.explanation: The question as shown is missing additional information (e.g., acceleration or whether it moves with constant velocity). The coefficient of kinetic friction cannot be uniquely determined from the given text alone.

questions.question: A block and tackle is used to raise a load of 25 N through a vertical distance of 30 m. What is the efficiency of the system if the work done against friction is 1500 J? [g ≈ 10 m s^-2]
questions.explanation: Useful work output = \(25\times 30 = 750\,J\). Input work = output + friction = \(750+1500=2250\,J\). Efficiency = \(\frac{750}{2250}\times 100\% = 33.3\%\). This is not among the provided options, indicating a mismatch in the question/options as shown in the image.

questions.question: If a load of 1 kg stretches a cord by 1.2 cm, what is the force constant of the cord? [g ≈ 10 m s^-2]
An object of volume 1 m3 and mass 2 kg is totally immersed in a liquid of density 1 kg m^-3. Calculate its apparent weight.
questions.explanation: Weight \(=mg=2\times 10=20\,N\). Upthrust \(=\rho gV=1\times 10\times 1=10\,N\). Apparent weight \(=20-10=10\,N\).

questions.question: The pressure at any point in a liquid at rest depends only on the
questions.explanation: Hydrostatic pressure depends on \(\rho\) and depth \(h\): \(p=\rho gh\).

questions.question: A balloon whose volume is 300 m3 is filled with hydrogen. If the density of air is 1.3 kg m^-3, find the up thrust on the balloon. [g ≈ 10 m s^-2]
questions.explanation: Upthrust equals weight of displaced air: \(F_b=\rho_{air}gV=1.3\times 10\times 300=3900\,N\).

questions.question: Clinical thermometers are examples of
questions.explanation: Clinical thermometers are mercury-in-glass thermometers.

questions.question: Two metals P and Q are heated through the same temperature difference. If the ratio of the linear expansivities of P to Q is 2:3 and the ratio of their lengths is 3:4 respectively, the ratio of the increase in lengths of P to Q is
questions.explanation: \(\Delta L \propto \alpha L\). Ratio \(\frac{\Delta L_P}{\Delta L_Q}=\frac{2}{3}\times\frac{3}{4}=\frac{1}{2}\Rightarrow 1:2\).

questions.question: 2000 cm3 of a gas is collected at 27°C and 700 mmHg. What is the volume of the gas at standard temperature and pressure?
Calculate the temperature change when 500 J of heat is supplied to 100 g of water. (Specific heat capacity of water = 4200 J kg^-1 K^-1)
questions.explanation: \(\Delta T=\frac{Q}{mc}=\frac{500}{0.1\times 4200}=1.19\,^{\circ}C\approx 1.2\,^{\circ}C\).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a factor that can increase the rate of evaporation of water in a lake?

options.text: Increase in the pressure of the atmosphere
Increase in the average speed of the molecules of water
Increase in the kinetic energy of the molecules of water

questions.explanation: Increased atmospheric pressure reduces evaporation; the other factors increase evaporation.

questions.question: The quantity of heat energy required to melt completely 1 kg of ice at -30°C is [latent heat of fusion = \(3.5\times 10^5\,J kg^{-1}\), specific heat capacity of ice = \(2.1\times 10^3\,J kg^{-1} K^{-1}\)]
questions.explanation: Total heat \(= mc\Delta T + mL = 1(2.1\times 10^3)(30) + 1(3.5\times 10^5)=6.3\times 10^4+3.5\times 10^5=4.13\times 10^5\,J\).

questions.question:
I. It is a rapid, constant and irregular motion of tiny particles.
II. It gives evidence that tiny particles of matter called molecules exist.
III. It takes place only in gases.
IV. It gives evidence that molecules are in a constant state of random motion.
Which of the combinations above is correct about Brownian motion?
questions.explanation: Brownian motion supports I, II, and IV; III is false because Brownian motion occurs in liquids as well.

questions.question: The equation of a wave travelling in a horizontal direction is expressed as \(y = 15\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{5}(60t-x)\right)\) what is its wavelength?
questions.explanation: The wave number \(k=\frac{2\pi}{5}\Rightarrow \lambda=\frac{2\pi}{k}=5\,m\).

questions.question: From the diagram above, if the particle F is at a distance x from O to the right, the phase of the vibration will be different from that at O by
questions.explanation: Phase difference over distance x is \(\Delta\phi=\frac{2\pi}{\lambda}x\).

questions.question: Which of the following factors will affect the velocity of sound?

options.text: An increase in the pitch of the sound
An increase in the loudness of the sound
Wind travelling in the same direction of the sound
A change in the atmospheric pressure at constant temperature

questions.explanation: Wind affects the speed of sound relative to the ground by adding/subtracting from the wave speed.

questions.question: The characteristics of a vibration that determines its intensity is the
questions.explanation: Intensity is proportional to the square of amplitude; larger amplitude gives greater intensity.

questions.question: Where a man can place his face to get an enlarged image when using a concave mirror to shave.

options.text: between the centre of curvature and the principal focus
between the principal focus and the pole
At the centre of the curvature

questions.explanation: For a concave mirror, an enlarged upright image is formed when the object is between the focal point and the pole.

questions.question: A pinhole camera is placed 300 m in front of a building so that the image is formed on a screen 5 cm from the pinhole. If the image is 2.5 cm high, the height of the building will be
The magnification of an object 2 cm tall when placed 10 cm in front of a plane mirror is
questions.explanation: Plane mirrors produce images of the same size as the object; magnification = 1.

questions.question: After reflection from concave mirror, rays of light from the sun converges
questions.explanation: Parallel rays from the sun converge at the principal focus of a concave mirror.

questions.question: A glass block of thickness 10 cm is placed on an object. If an observer views the object vertically, the displacement of the object is
questions.explanation: For glass \(n\approx 1.5\): apparent depth \(=\frac{10}{1.5}=6.67\,cm\). Displacement \(=10-6.67=3.33\,cm\).

questions.question:
I. Rays of light travel from a less dense medium to a denser medium
II. The angle of incidence is greater than critical angle.
III. Rays of light travel from a denser medium to a less dense medium
Which of the statements above are conditions for total internal reflection to occur?
questions.explanation: Total internal reflection requires (III) denser to less dense, and (II) angle of incidence greater than critical angle.

questions.question: The use of lenses is NOT applicable in the
questions.explanation: A periscope primarily uses mirrors/prisms rather than lenses.

questions.question: Dispersion of white light is the ability of white light to
questions.explanation: Dispersion means splitting white light into its component colours.

questions.question: A newly charged 12 V accumulator can easily start a car whereas eight new dry cells in series with an effective e.m.f. of 12 V cannot start the same car because

options.text: It cannot easily be connected to a car

questions.explanation: Dry cells cannot supply the large current needed (high internal resistance/low current capacity).

questions.question: Six identical cells, each of e.m.f. 2 V are connected as shown above. The effective e.m.f. of the cell is
questions.explanation: The connection diagram is not readable enough to determine how many cells are effectively in series/opposition, so the resultant e.m.f. cannot be determined reliably from the upload.

questions.question: The fuse in an electric devise is always connected to the ----

options.text: Neutral side of an electric supply
Earth side of an electric supply
Live side of an electric supply
Terminal side of an electric supply

questions.explanation: The fuse is connected in the live wire to cut off the supply when it melts.

questions.question: A particle carrying a charge of \(1.0\times 10^{-8}\,C\) enters a magnetic field at \(3.0\times 10^2\,m s^{-1}\) at right angles to the field. If the force on this particle is \(1.8\times 10^{-8}\,N\), what is the magnitude of the field?
Which of the following is the correct shape of the graph of capacitive reactance \(X_c\) versus frequency F for a pure capacitor in an a.c. circuit?
questions.explanation: Since \(X_c=\frac{1}{2\pi f C}\), \(X_c\) decreases as frequency increases, giving a falling hyperbola.

questions.question: The current output form of an a.c. source is given as \(I = 10\sin \omega t\). The d.c. equivalent of the current is
questions.explanation: DC equivalent (rms) \(=\frac{10}{\sqrt{2}}\approx 7.1\,A\).

questions.question: A conductor of length 1 m moves with a velocity of 50 m s^-1 at an angle of 30° to the direction of a uniform magnetic field of flux density 1.5 Wb m^-2. What is the e.m.f. induced in the conductor?
questions.explanation: \(\mathcal{E}=Blv\sin\theta = 1.5\times 1\times 50\times \sin 30^\circ=37.5\,V\).

questions.question: The process of detecting a pin mistakenly swallowed by a child is
questions.explanation: X-ray detection is diagnostic.

questions.question: Which of the following particles CANNOT be deflected by both electric and magnetic fields?
questions.explanation: Gamma rays are uncharged electromagnetic radiation.

questions.question: A piece of radioactive material contains 1000 atoms. If its half-life is 20 seconds, the time taken for 125 atoms to remain is
questions.explanation: Three half-lives reduce 1000 → 500 → 250 → 125, so time = 3×20 = 60 s.

questions.question: The p-n junction diodes can act as rectifiers because they
questions.explanation: A diode conducts significantly only when forward biased, allowing one-way current flow.

questions.question: If a reverse-biased voltage is applied across a p-n junction, the depletion layer width is
questions.explanation: Reverse bias increases the potential barrier and widens the depletion region.

questions.question:
I. Small size
II. Low power requirement
III. Not easily damaged by high temperature
IV. Highly durable
Which of the above are the advantages of semiconductors?
questions.explanation: Semiconductor devices are generally small, require low power, and are durable. However they can be sensitive to high temperature (performance degrades), so III is not an advantage.
